prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN J=4-3 Settings 1-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observation of HCN and H13CN J=4-3 in the ground and vibrationally excited states to study the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. Settings 1-4 cover the range 363.213-366.938 GHz in USB and 351.215-354.938 in LSB. Requested sensitivity is 4 mJy (3.9 K) with angular resolution of 0.1".
The expected line fluxes are well above 100 K, reaching 2000 K for line opacities of the order of unity (see scientific justification).
Requested spectral resolution is 1 km/s. The total observing time is 1.38 hours.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. The selected spectral resolution and band coverage allow to achieve the goals in a resonable observing time. The velocity resolution of 1 km/s is absolutely necessary to follow the expansion of the gas.

Subtructures of less than 0.4" within the region r<4" are expected as a function of the velocity (the gas is expanding at 14.5 km/s following a complex spiral and uncomplete shells pattern -see Figure 2). Hence, the requested angular resolution will permit to trace the spatial structure of the innemost layers of IRC+10216.

The aim of the proposed observations is to study the dust formation zone of IRC which covers the region between 1 and 20-30 stellar radii (0.02-1/1.5"). The requested sensitivity (5 K in a 0.1" beam) will permit to follow the gas distribution for abundant species (HCN, H13CN, SiC2, SiO, SiS, Si2C, etc) up to 4" where the kinetic temperature decreases to 100 K. Optically thick lines will be detected up to this distance with a S/N of 20.

The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. High data rate is needed to minimize observing time and to get the best spectral resolution study of the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. A spectral average of 2 channels is requested without loosing the goal of 1 km/s of spectral resolution.

The lines in IRC+10216 are broad but we adress the study of the dust formation zone where the acceleration of the gas is produced. Single polarization provides a better velocity resolution, of the order of 0.8 km/s with a sampling of 0.4 km/s. It is preferred over dual polarization to study at high angular resolution the region 0-1.5" where the gas change its velocity from 0 to 14.5 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN J=4-3 Settings 5-8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observation of HCN and H13CN J=4-3 in the ground and vibrationally excited states to study the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. Settings 5-8 cover the range 359.54-363.24 GHz in USB and 347.51-351.24 in LSB. Requested sensitivity is 4 mJy (4 K) with angular resolution of 0.1".
The expected line fluxes are well above 100 K, reaching 2000 K for line opacities of the order of unity near the star (see scientific justification).
Requested spectral resolution is 1 km/s. The total observing time is 1.15 hours.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. The selected spectral resolution and band coverage allow to achieve the goals in a resonable observing time. The velocity resolution of 1 km/s is absolutely necessary to follow the expansion of the gas.

Subtructures of less than 0.4" within the region r<4" are expected as a function of the velocity (the gas is expanding at 14.5 km/s following a complex spiral and uncomplete shells pattern -see Figure 2). Hence, the requested angular resolution will permit to trace the spatial structure of the innemost layers of IRC+10216.

The aim of the proposed observations is to study the dust formation zone of IRC which covers the region between 1 and 20-30 stellar radii (0.02-1/1.5"). The requested sensitivity (5 K in a 0.1" beam) will permit to follow the gas distribution for abundant species (HCN, H13CN, SiC2, SiO, SiS, Si2C, etc) up to 4" where the kinetic temperature decreases to 100 K. Optically thick lines will be detected up to this distance with a S/N of 20.

The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. High data rate is needed to minimize observing time and to get the best spectral resolution study of the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. A spectral average of 2 channels is requested without loosing the goal of 1 km/s of spectral resolution.

The lines in IRC+10216 are broad but we adress the study of the dust formation zone where the acceleration of the gas is produced. Single polarization provides a better velocity resolution, of the order of 0.8 km/s with a sampling of 0.4 km/s. It is preferred over dual polarization to study at high angular resolution the region 0-1.5" where the gas change its velocity from 0 to 14.5 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN v#0 J=4-3 Settings 9-12
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observation of HCN and H13CN J=4-3 in the ground and vibrationally excited states to study the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. Settings 9-12 cover the range 355.813-359.538 GHz in USB and 343.813-347.538 GHz in LSB. Requested sensitivity is 5 mJy (29.7 K) with angular resolution of 0.04".
The expected line fluxes are well above 100 K, reaching 2000 K for line opacities of the order of unity near the star (see scientific justification).
Spectral resolution is 1 km/s. The total observing time is 1.70 hours.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. The selected spectral resolution and band coverage allow to achieve the goals in a resonable observing time. The velocity resolution of 1 km/s is absolutely necessary to follow the expansion of the gas.

The aim of the proposed observations is to study the dust formation zone of IRC which covers the region between 1 and 20-30 stellar radii (0.02-1/1.5"). The requested sensitivity (23 K in a 0.04" beam) will permit to follow the gas distribution for abundant species (HCN, H13CN, SiC2, SiO, SiS, Si2C, etc) up to 3-4" where the kinetic temperature decreases to 100 K with spatial resolution to resolve the structure of the spiral arms and arcs observed in cycle0. Subtructures of less than 0.4" within the region r<4" are expected as a function of the velocity (the gas is expanding at 14.5 km/s following a complex spiral and uncomplete shells pattern -see Figure 2). This in the only non-standard science goal requested in the proposal.

The aim of the proposed observations is to study the dust formation zone of IRC which covers the region between 1 and 20-30 stellar radii (0.02-1/1.5"). The requested sensitivity (29 K in a 0.04" beam) will permit to follow the gas distribution for abundant species (HCN, H13CN, SiC2, SiO, SiS, Si2C, etc) up to 1.5" where the kinetic temperature decreases to 200 K. The lines of these species will exhibit intensities close to 1000-2400 K between 0-0.4", and 200 K at 1.5". Hence, the minimum S/N of the whole map will be around 7.
In this SG we request for a higher angular resolution to study in detail the dust growth zone using the lines of H13CN and HC15N (both mapped in Cycle0 with 0.7" of angular resolution, see Figure 2 of the proposal). The requested angular resolution corresponds to the angular size of the central star and will provide an unique view of the gas around it, its kinematics and the chemistry. Lines from many species, many of them still to be identified (see Figure 1 of the proposal) will be detected in this SG.

The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. High data rate is needed to minimize observing time and to get the best spectral resolution study of the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. A spectral average of 2 channels is requested without loosing the goal of 1 km/s of spectral resolution.

The lines in IRC+10216 are broad but we adress the study of the dust formation zone where the acceleration of the gas is produced. Single polarization provides a better velocity resolution, of the order of 0.8 km/s with a sampling of 0.4 km/s. It is preferred over dual polarization to study at high angular resolution the region 0-1.5" where the gas change its velocity from 0 to 14.5 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN J=4-3 Settings 13-16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observation of HCN and H13CN J=4-3 in the ground and vibrationally excited states to study the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. Settings 13-16 cover the range 352.113-355.838 GHz in USB and 340.113-343.838 GHz in LSB. Requested sensitivity is 4 mJy (4.1 K) with angular resolution of 0.1".
The expected line fluxes are well above 100 K, reaching 2000 K for line opacities of the order of unity near the star (see scientific justification).
Spectral resolution is 1 km/s.Total observing is 1.14 hours.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. The selected spectral resolution and band coverage allow to achieve the goals in a resonable observing time. The velocity resolution of 1 km/s is absolutely necessary to follow the expansion of the gas.

Subtructures of less than 0.4" within the region r<4" are expected as a function of the velocity (the gas is expanding at 14.5 km/s following a complex spiral and uncomplete shells pattern -see Figure 2). Hence, the requested angular resolution will permit to trace the spatial structure of the innemost layers of IRC+10216.

The aim of the proposed observations is to study the dust formation zone of IRC which covers the region between 1 and 20-30 stellar radii (0.02-1/1.5"). The requested sensitivity (5 K in a 0.1" beam) will permit to follow the gas distribution for abundant species (HCN, H13CN, SiC2, SiO, SiS, Si2C, etc) up to 3-4" where the kinetic temperature decreases to 100 K. Optically thick lines will be detected up to this distance with a S/N of 20.

The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. High data rate is needed to minimize observing time and to get the best spectral resolution study of the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. A spectral average of 2 channels is requested without loosing the goal of 1 km/s of spectral resolution.

The lines in IRC+10216 are broad but we adress the study of the dust formation zone where the acceleration of the gas is produced. Single polarization provides a better velocity resolution, of the order of 0.8 km/s with a sampling of 0.4 km/s. It is preferred over dual polarization to study at high angular resolution the region 0-1.5" where the gas change its velocity from 0 to 14.5 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Extended map of H13CN J=4-3, HC15N J=4-3 , CO J=3-2 and other species
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Mosaic maps of H13CN and HC15N J=4-3 in the ground and vibrationally excited states to study the spatial ditribution of matter and the mass loss history of IRC+10216. The frequency settings are those of Science Goal N3. Requested sensitivity is 5 mJy (0.5 K) with angular resolution of 0.3". The map will consist of 7 positions to cover a region 27"x27" in size (at half power intensity of the single dish).
The expected line fluxes are well above 100 K, reaching 2000 K for line opacities of the order of unity near the star (see scientific justification).
Spectral resolution is 1 km/s. The total observing time is 2.21 hours.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The proposal aims to cover a 26 GHz band. The selected spectral resolution and band coverage allow to achieve the goals in a resonable observing time. The velocity resolution of 1 km/s is absolutely necessary to follow the expansion of the gas.

A map of 20"x20" seems reasonable in view of the cycle0 maps of H13CN and HC15N J=3-2 obtained with angular resolution of 0.7" (see Figure 2 of the proposal). Subtructures of less than 0.4" within the region r<10" are expected as a function of the velocity (the gas is expanding at 14.5 km/s following a complex spiral and uncomplete shells pattern -see Figure 2). The angular resolution selected, 0.3", will permit to follow the gas in different tracers up to 10-12" and to study the clumpy structure of the ejected gas.

The aim of the proposed observations in this science goal is to map a more extended region than the dust formation zone. The requested sensitivity (0.6 K in a 0.3" beam) will permit to follow the gas distribution for abundant species (HCN, H13CN, SiC2, SiO, SiS, Si2C, etc) up to 12" where the kinetic temperature decreases to 40-50 K and the abundant species could have intensities > 5 K (from single dish observations with the 30-m IRAM radio telescope). The data for the central position of the mosaic could be merged with those of SG3 (0.04") to increase the sensitivity.

This setting aims to map a large region in the same frequency settings than Science Goal N3 but with an angular resolution of 0.3". We need to cover the lines of H13CN, HC15N and other molecules that are inside the covered frequency range. High data rate is needed to minimize observing time and to get the best spectral resolution study of the dust formation zone of IRC+10216. A spectral average of 2 channels is requested without loosing the goal of 1 km/s of spectral resolution.

The lines in IRC+10216 are broad but we adress the study of the dust formation zone where the acceleration of the gas is produced. Single polarization provides a better velocity resolution, of the order of 0.8 km/s with a sampling of 0.4 km/s. It is preferred over dual polarization to study at high angular resolution the region 0-1.5" where the gas change its velocity from 0 to 14.5 km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe the J=4-3 line of HCN in all its vibrational states below 15000 K using the longest baselines provided by ALMA Cycle 3. These transitions will trace the physical conditions of the dust formation zone, corresponding to 5<r<20 R* (0.04"<r<1"). The requested angular resolution, 0.04", will permit to fully resolve the warm region, and will allow to derive the spatial distribution of the gas around the central star. In the proposed frequency coverage of these lines (around 26 GHz) we will also observe lines of SiO, SiS, CS, HC3N, CO, HCO+ and many isotopologues. Hence, this proposal will provide the highest angular resolution and sensitivity view of the physical and chemical conditions of the dust formation zone of IRC+10216.
Finally, the proposed observations will also provide a very sensitive view of the molecular content of the warm intermediate envelope (layers inside a radius of 10"). One of the frequency settings will be also observed over a 20"x20" with an angular resolution of 0.3" and a sensitivity of 0.5 K.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00237.S, A high angular resolution study of the dust formation zone of IRC+10216, PI: J. Cernicharo (Cycle 1 moved to Cycle 2)
